thread.title: ANGELS: Pitching coach Butcher, hitting coach Baylor let go
thread.title_full: ANGELS: Pitching coach Butcher, hitting coach Baylor let go - Press Enterprise

author: JEFF FLETCHER
title: ANGELS: Pitching coach Butcher, hitting coach Baylor let go
text:
BY JEFF FLETCHER / STAFF WRITER
Published: Oct. 13, 2015 Updated: Oct. 14, 2015 10:09 a.m. ANAHEIM – Mike Butcher, the Angels pitching coach for the past nine seasons, and hitting coach Don Baylor will not be back next season, the first significant moves by new general manager Billy Eppler.
Both coaches were in the final year of their contracts this season.
The Angels announced the moves on Tuesday night, with Eppler issuing complimentary statements about both Baylor and Butcher.
“These are good baseball men and individuals who have a deep passion and focus for their craft,” Eppler said in the statement. “I am both respectful and appreciative of the many contributions Don and Mike have made to this organization during their careers here.”
Butcher, 50, also issued a statement in which he said he and the club’s management “mutually agreed this might be a good time for a change.”
Under Butcher’s tutelage, the Angels had a 3.94 ERA this season, sixth in the American League.
Hector Santiago, Andrew Heaney and Garrett Richards had publicly complimented him for their improvement over the past two years.
Butcher also oversaw the decline of Jered Weaver, as well as Richards’ inability to match his breakthrough performance in 2014.
Baylor, 66, completed his second season as the Angels hitting coach. The team led the majors in runs in 2014, but slipped to 12th in the league this season.
A former MVP with the Angels, Baylor has spent 23 years as a major league manager or hitting coach.
His season got off to a dubious start in 2014, when he fractured his leg when he slipped during a pregame ceremony. Baylor has been back on the job full time since the middle of the 2014 season, but he was still noticeably hobbled this season.
